name: Interpreting Absolute Values in Real-World Situations

skills.name: Perform calculations with temperature when given in the same units
Interpret absolute value in real-world contexts

explanations.A: To make his balance back up to $0, Marcus would have to pay $35. This means he owes the bank $35.
explanations.B: Not quite - when we 'owe' someone, it's how much we would have to pay them so that we owe them $0. We wouldn't really ever owe a negative amount of money!
explanations.C: Owing the bank doesn't mean having no money. When thinking about how much we 'owe the bank', it means how much we would have to pay to make our balance back to $0.
explanations.D: Not quite. When we're thinking about how much we 'owe', it's how much we would need to pay to take the balance to $0.

explanations.A: Not quite - when we 'owe' someone, it's how much we would have to pay them so that we owe them $0. We wouldn't really ever owe a negative amount of money!
explanations.B: Not quite. When we're thinking about how much we 'owe', it's how much we would need to pay to take the balance to $0.
explanations.C: Owing the bank doesn't mean having no money. When thinking about how much we 'owe the bank', it means how much we would have to pay to make our balance back to $0.
explanations.D: To make his balance back up to $0, John would have to pay $25. This means he owes the bank $25!

explanations.A: Not quite - when we 'owe' someone, it's how much we would have to pay them so that we owe them $0. We wouldn't really ever owe a negative amount of money!
explanations.B: Close, but it looks like you might have included $15 when counting down by 4. We don't include the number we're starting on when subtracting.
explanations.C: If she has paid $4, then she owes $4 less than $15, which is $11.
explanations.D: It seems like you've added the $4 and the $15 together, but if she has paid him some money, she should owe him less rather than more!

explanations.A: It seems like you've added the $25 and the $12 together, but if she has paid him some money, she should owe him less rather than more!
explanations.B: If she has paid $12, then she owes $12 less than $25, which is $13.
explanations.C: Close, but it looks like you might have included $25 when counting down by 12. We don't include the number we're starting on when subtracting.
explanations.D: Not quite - when we 'owe' someone, it's how much we would have to pay them so that we owe them $0. We wouldn't really ever owe a negative amount of money!

explanations.A: It looks like you've subtracted 23 from 4, however that would tell us the difference between +23 and +4 rather than -23. Try thinking about how far away each value is from 0!
explanations.B: 4 is '4' away from 0, and then -23 is '23' away from 0 in the other direction. That means to get from 4 to -23, we would need to subtract 4, then 23, so the total difference in temperature is 27!
explanations.C: It looks like you've found the difference between 4 and positive 23 rather than negative 23. Try thinking about how far each number is away from 0!
explanations.D: When giving the difference between two values, we don't usually give a negative symbol. We know in this question that the temperature has decreased as it tells us, so we only need to give how many degrees it's fallen by!

explanations.A: It looks like you've found the difference between 6 and positive 27 rather than negative 27. Try thinking about how far each number is away from 0!
explanations.B: When giving the difference between two values, we don't usually give a negative symbol. We know in this question that the temperature has decreased as it tells us, so we only need to give how many degrees it's fallen by!
explanations.C: It looks like you've subtracted 27 from 6, however that would tell us the difference between +27 and +6 rather than -27. Try thinking about how far away each value is from 0!
explanations.D: 6 is '6' away from 0, and then -27 is '27' away from 0 in the other direction. That means to get from 6 to -27, we would need to subtract 6, then 27, so the total difference in temperature is 33!

explanations.A: Very close, but try thinking about what the absolute value of -47 is.
explanations.B: Very close, but try thinking about what the absolute value of -47 is.
explanations.C: Not quite - distance can't be given as a negative, only as an absolute value!
explanations.D: The absolute value of -47 is 47, so both A and B would be correct as they're the same!

explanations.A: Not quite - distance can't be given as a negative, only as an absolute value!

explanations.D: The absolute value of -36 is 36, so both B and C would be correct as they're the same!

explanations.A: Not quite - distance can't be given as a negative, only as an absolute value!
explanations.B: Close but it looks like you counted the number you started on when subtracting. We start counting from the next number down!
explanations.C: It looks like you've subtracted 2 from 18, however that would tell us the difference between +18 and +2 rather than -2. Try thinking about how far away each value is from 0!
explanations.D: 18 is 18 above 0, and -2 is 2 below 0, so in total there is a difference of 20.

explanations.A: Close but it looks like you counted the number you started on when subtracting. We start counting from the next number down!
explanations.B: 16 is 16 above 0, and -3 is 3 below 0, so in total there is a difference of 19.
explanations.C: Not quite - distance can't be given as a negative, only as an absolute value!
explanations.D: It looks like you've subtracted 3 from 16, however that would tell us the difference between +16 and +3 rather than -3. Try thinking about how far away each value is from 0!
